description.narrative:
The scope of the MoU between FAO and Italy is to facilitate a way for the latter to provide funds for the implementation of the USD 40million Masterplan study prepared in year 2014 by the Ministry of Infrastructure (MIT). The 15 year duration of the MoU guarantees quality assurance of implemented works over extended periods of time, during which technical issues may emerge and therefore additional costs incurred. The MoU does not prevent Italy and FAO to conclude (overlapping) funding agreements to progressively finance the implementation of the afore-mentioned Masterplan, nor impacts on the work plan of the MIT which is presently consolidating the stone facades of the headquarters buildings.
The first contribution for the implementation of EUR 2 Million involves 4 projects as follows:
1. Increase safety of the Plenary Room by restoring the artistic plaster ceiling titled ?Universo? by Mirko Basaldella. Cost estimate: EUR 660 000. Timing estimate: completion in 24 months from the approval by the Italian Authorities. 2. Consolidation of the wall, surface conservation and clearing of the entire area. Cost estimate: EUR 410 000. Timing estimate: completion in 24 months from the approval by the Italian Authorities. 3. Structural assessment study of the buildings (A and B) buildings. Cost estimate: EUR 200 000. Timing estimate: completion within 24 months. 4. Replacement of curtain walls between Building B and C. Cost estimate: EUR 730 000. Timing estimate: completion within 24 months from the approval by the Italian Authorities
After 5 years since the finalization of a USD40million Masterplan for extraordinary maintenance work for the FAO headquarters buildings, a long term solution has been found. To date, CSDI has had to mitigate high risk and life threatening risks deriving from the poor conditions of the FAO buildings while granting work to staff and holding large events and meetings. Loose stone facing, falling objects, dangerous windows, old and obsolete electrical systems, minimal fire detection systems, flammable materials, insufficient safety exits, structural weaknesses, lack of seismic study and much more have been on FAO?s plate well before the completion of the Masterplan and have generated innumerable correspondence from FAO and meetings requesting repair work and funding.
